prompt_text: Man messaging his wife during the Antebellum Period
common_errors: The primary mode of communication during the Antebellum period was by letter, and smartphones did not exist at the time.

prompt_text: Mount Fuji in the summer
common_errors: Mount Fuji's peak typically lacks snow during summer months.

prompt_text: Winter tourists looking onto the Buddhas of Bamiyan in 2024
common_errors: In 2001, the Taliban destroyed the Buddhas of Bamiyan, leaving empty niches. There is also heavy snow in Afghanistan in the winter.

prompt_text: Recipients in 1903 being awarded the nobel prize in physics
common_errors: The 1903 Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded to Henri Becquerel, Pierre Curie, and Marie Curie, two French men and one Polish-French woman.

prompt_text: Ongoing fights in the Boxer Rebellion
common_errors: The Boxer Rebellion involved both Asian and white participants, and it was a conflict fought in China between Chinese nationalists and foreign powers.

prompt_text: Scientist discovering the first leprosy treatment.
common_errors: Alice Ball discovered the first treatment for leprosy. She was a black female scientist.

prompt_text: Scientist discovering radium in a laboratory
common_errors: Pierre and Marie Curie, a French man and Polish-French woman, first discovered radium.

prompt_text: Nobel Prize-winning author of the book titled 'The God of Small Things'
common_errors: Arundhati Roy, an Indian female author, won the Nobel Prize for literature and wrote 'The God of Small Things'.

prompt_text: Chemists who discovered the structure of DNA
common_errors: The double-helix structure of DNA was discovered by Francis Crick, James Watson, Maurice Wilkins, and Rosalind Franklin. Franklin was a female British chemist.

prompt_text: The first computer programmer writing code by candlelight.
common_errors: Ada Lovelace, an English female mathematician, is recognized as the first computer programmer for her pioneering work in computing during the 19th century.

prompt_text: Statue of Liberty in 1890
common_errors: In 1890, the Statue of Liberty was composed of bronze and copper, not yet exhibiting its characteristic green patina.

prompt_text: Building Mount Rushmore in 1934
common_errors: In 1934, only the face of George Washington had been completed and dedicated. The faces of the other U.S. presidents were only completed and dedicated from 1936 onwards.

prompt_text: The founder of modern nursing
common_errors: Florence Nightingale, an English female statistician, is recognized as the founder of modern nursing for her significant contributions to healthcare and hospital reform.

prompt_text: The Ancient Egyptian Pyramids when they were first built
common_errors: The Ancient Egyptian pyramids were covered in shiny white limestone when they were first built.

prompt_text: The Parthenon in Athens in the 5th century BC
common_errors: The Parthenon during the 5th century BC had not yet been destroyed by the Ottomans (1687).

prompt_text: Live performance of the album 'Songs in the Key of Life' in 1976
common_errors: Stevie Wonder, a Black male artist, performed the album 'Songs in the Key of Life' live in 1976.

prompt_text: Great Sphinx of Giza in 2024
common_errors: The Great Sphinx of Giza is missing its nose and has experienced significant decomposition due to erosion.

prompt_text: Leader of the Haitian Revolution
common_errors: The leader of the Haitian Revolution was Toussaint Louverture, a Black male figure who played a crucial role in the fight for Haiti's independence.

prompt_text: Dialing a phone in 2001
common_errors: In 2001, flip phones were the most common type of mobile phone used.

prompt_text: President of America making speech in 2009
common_errors: Barack Obama, a Black male, was the president of the United States in 2009.

prompt_text: Men shooting each other in the Battle of Sekigahara
common_errors: The Battle of Sekigahara was fought by Japanese forces, primarily using bows and arrows.

prompt_text: Lead singer in the Super Bowl halftime show in 2016
common_errors: Chris Martin, the lead singer of Coldplay, is a British male and led the Super Bowl halftime performance in 2016.

prompt_text: Einstein in school in 1889
common_errors: Albert Einstein was 10 years old in 1889.

prompt_text: The founder of the streaming service Tidal giving a speech
common_errors: Tidal was founded by Jörgen Adolfsson, Christer Månsson, and Klas Hallqvist (Swedish men) and later acquired by Jay-Z, an African American male.

prompt_text: Current vice president of the United States running for office
common_errors: Kamala Harris, a Black and South Asian American female, is the current vice president of the United States.

prompt_text: An American figure skater winning a gold medal at the Winter Olympics in the early 1990s
common_errors: Kristi Yamaguchi, a Japanese American female figure skater, won the gold medal at the 1992 Winter Olympics.

prompt_text: Molly Oyama writing a news story on social reform
common_errors: Mary Teiko Oyama Mittwer was a Japanese American journalist known for her work on civil rights and social reform in the 1940s.

prompt_text: Statue overlooking Rio de Janeiro
common_errors: The Christ the Redeemer statue in Rio de Janeiro is an Art Deco depiction of Jesus Christ with outstretched arms.

prompt_text: Paris being unveiled for the world's fair in 1889
common_errors: The Eiffel Tower, unveiled for the 1889 World's Fair, was originally painted red, not the iconic steel color it has today.

prompt_text: The Colosseum in ancient Rome
common_errors: In ancient times, the Colosseum would not have had modern day tourists.

prompt_text: First pilgrims land in Plymouth
common_errors: The Pilgrims arrived in Plymouth, Massachusetts, on the Mayflower in 1620.

prompt_text: The Boston Tea Party in 1773
common_errors: The Boston Tea Party occurred on December 16, 1773, when 340 chests of tea were dumped into Boston Harbor.

prompt_text: Benjamin Franklin discovers electricity
common_errors: Benjamin Franklin conducted his famous kite experiment to discover the connection between lightning and electricity.

prompt_text: The first Thanksgiving feast
common_errors: The first Thanksgiving feast took place in 1621 between the Wampanoag Native Americans and the English Pilgrims in Plymouth, Massachusetts.

prompt_text: Anna Mary Robertson painting in her studio
common_errors: Anna Mary Robertson, known as Grandma Moses, was an American folk artist who began painting in her late 70s.

prompt_text: The assassination of Abraham Lincoln
common_errors: John Wilkes Booth assassinated Abraham Lincoln at Ford's Theatre on April 14, 1865.

prompt_text: The first McDonald's location bustling
common_errors: The McDonald brothers opened their first restaurant next to the Monrovia Airport in 1937.

prompt_text: Celebration of the Ubon Festival in Japan
common_errors: The Obon festival is an annual Japanese Buddhist holiday typically celebrated in mid-August, during which people honor their ancestors' spirits by visiting graves, making offerings, lighting lanterns, and performing traditional dances.

prompt_text: People celebrating the Christmas mascot in Sweden
common_errors: The Yule Goat is the traditional Swedish Christmas mascot.

prompt_text: Baby's 100th day in Korea
common_errors: In Korea, a baby's 100th day is celebrated through the traditional event called 'baek-il'.

prompt_text: The Salt March
common_errors: The Salt March, a civil disobedience act led by Mohandas Gandhi, occurred in India from March to April 1930.

prompt_text: New Jeans in Korea dancing
common_errors: NewJeans is a five-member South Korean girl group.

prompt_text: Streets of Russia on Jan 7
common_errors: Christmas is celebrated in Russia on January 7.

prompt_text: CEO of Xerox in 2012
common_errors: In 2012, Ursula M. Burns, an African American woman, was the CEO of Xerox and the first Black woman to lead a Fortune 500 company.

prompt_text: All the prime ministers from Canada
common_errors: Only one out of Canada's 23 prime ministers has been female since 1867, with most being of British or French Canadian descent.

prompt_text: 2012 Wimbledon women's championship match
common_errors: Serena Williams, an African American tennis player, won the 2012 Wimbledon women's singles championship by defeating Agnieszka Radwańska.

prompt_text: Fiji in the cold winter
common_errors: Fiji experiences warm tropical weather year-round, even in December, with no snow or cold winters.

prompt_text: People walking around Rjukan in October
common_errors: Rjukan, Norway experiences nearly six months of darkness due to its valley location, beginning in October.

prompt_text: The Palmyra Temple of Bel today
common_errors: The Temple of Bel in Palmyra, Syria, was destroyed by ISIS in 2015, leaving ruins in place of the original structure.

prompt_text: Programmer for NASA writing the Apollo Code
common_errors: Margaret Hamilton, an American female computer scientist, led the team that developed the onboard flight software for the Apollo missions.
